verses.text: And a great sign appeared in heaven: a woman clothed with the sun, with the moon under her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve stars.
verses.comment: The woman is commonly interpreted as representing both Israel and the faithful people of God, and also traditionally as a figure of Mary, the mother of Jesus. The twelve stars symbolize the twelve tribes or apostles, linking Old and New Covenant people.

verses.text: She was pregnant and cried out in pain, in the agony of giving birth.
verses.comment: This verse shows deep fulfillment themes, alluding to prophecies of a Messiah born from the people of God (see Isaiah references).

verses.text: And another sign appeared in heaven: behold, a great red dragon, with seven heads and ten horns, and on his heads seven crowns.
verses.comment: The dragon is a symbol for Satan. The imagery of multiple heads and horns represents earthly powers opposed to God, recalling Daniel’s visions.

verses.text: His tail swept away a third of the stars of heaven and threw them to the earth. And the dragon stood before the woman who was about to give birth, so that when she gave birth, he might devour her child.
verses.comment: The stars likely represent fallen angels. The hostility toward the child mirrors the threats to Jesus as a newborn (Herod), showing satanic opposition to the Messiah.

verses.text: She gave birth to a male child, who is destined to rule all nations with a rod of iron. Her child was caught up to God and to his throne.
verses.comment: The male child clearly refers to Jesus, fulfilling prophecies of the Messiah ruling nations (Psalm 2:9). His ascension to God’s throne is Christological, emphasizing his divine authority.

verses.text: The woman fled into the wilderness, where she has a place prepared by God, so that she might be nourished there for 1,260 days.
verses.comment: 1,260 days links to a prophetic period of tribulation. The woman's flight mirrors other biblical escapes protected by God, pointing to God’s providence for his people.

verses.text: Then war broke out in heaven: Michael and his angels fighting against the dragon. And the dragon and his angels fought back,
verses.comment: Michael is seen as the leader of the heavenly hosts. This war expresses a spiritual reality of good versus evil, underpinning the cosmic conflict.

verses.text: but they were defeated, and there was no longer any place for them in heaven.
verses.comment: Satan's defeat signifies a decisive moment in salvation history, paralleling Jesus’ own words about Satan’s fall.

verses.text: And the great dragon was thrown down—the ancient serpent, who is called the devil and Satan, the deceiver of the whole world. He was thrown down to the earth, and his angels were thrown down with him.
verses.comment: Here, the dragon is identified with the serpent from Eden. The emphasis on deception highlights why resistance to evil requires spiritual armor (Eph. 6:11).

verses.text: Then I heard a loud voice in heaven, saying, "Now the salvation and the power and the kingdom of our God, and the authority of his Christ, have come. For the accuser of our brothers, who accuses them day and night before our God, has been thrown down."
verses.comment: Celebration of Christ’s victory and vindication of the faithful. This proclaims the defeat of Satan as accuser, anticipating full redemption and the unity of believers under Christ’s authority.

verses.text: And they overcame him by the blood of the Lamb and by the word of their testimony, and they did not love their lives even unto death.
verses.comment: The blood of the Lamb is central to Christian redemption, recalling Passover and Christ’s sacrifice. True witness involves costly faithfulness, even unto martyrdom.

verses.text: Therefore, rejoice, O heavens and you who dwell in them! But woe to the earth and the sea, for the devil has come down to you in great anger, knowing that his time is short.
verses.comment: A clear division between the security of heaven and struggles on earth. This points toward eschatological hope and perseverance for the faithful on earth.

verses.text: When the dragon saw that he had been thrown down to the earth, he pursued the woman who had given birth to the male child.
verses.comment: Echoes satanic attempts to destroy the faithful, which can be seen in the flight to Egypt. God’s providence continues to protect his chosen.

verses.text: But the woman was given the two wings of the great eagle, so that she might fly to the place prepared for her in the wilderness, where she would be nourished for a time, times, and half a time, away from the presence of the serpent.
verses.comment: Eagle’s wings recall God’s deliverance of Israel. The symbolic period mirrors other biblical periods of trial, suggesting spiritual growth through tribulation.

verses.text: And the serpent poured water like a river out of his mouth after the woman, to sweep her away with the flood.
verses.comment: Floods often symbolize overwhelming danger or evil in Scripture, yet also show God’s ability to deliver the faithful from spiritual threats.

verses.text: But the earth helped the woman, and the earth opened its mouth and swallowed up the river that the dragon had poured from his mouth.
verses.comment: Earth’s intervention recalls miraculous divine aid, symbolizing protection and support for God’s people—interpretable as spiritual refuge provided through God's means.

verses.text: Then the dragon was furious with the woman, and went off to make war on the rest of her offspring, on those who keep God’s commandments and hold to the testimony of Jesus. And he stood on the shore of the sea.
verses.comment: The offspring are faithful believers, highlighting that the struggle against evil continues. The connection to Genesis 3:15 shows the enmity between the serpent and the woman's seed, enduring throughout salvation history.
